chapter_title: DC Electrics - Circuit Protection and Capacitors

questions.question: In a circuit fitted with a non-trip free circuit breaker if a fault occurs and persists:
options: a. if the reset button is depressed and held in, the circuit will be made
b. the trip button may be pressed to reset, but not permanently
c. a non-trip free circuit breaker can never be bypassed
d. the reset button may be pressed to make the circuit permanent

questions.question: A trip free circuit breaker that has tripped due to overload:
options: a. can be reset and held in during rectification
b. can never be reset
c. can be reset after overhaul
d. may be reset manually after fault has been cleared

questions.question: Circuit breakers and fuses:
options: a. are used in DC circuits only
b. are used in AC or DC circuits
c. are used in AC circuits only
d. are used in low current circuits only

questions.question: A trip free circuit breaker is one which:
options: a. cannot be reset by holding the lever in while the fault persists
b. can be reset by holding the lever in while the fault persists
c. must be held in during checks to find faults
d. can be bypassed

questions.question: If the reset button is pressed in the trip free circuit breaker, the contacts with the fault cleared will:
options: a. be made and kept made
b. only be made if there is a fuse in the circuit
c. reset itself only after a delay of 20 seconds
d. not be made and the reset will remain inoperative

questions.question: A circuit breaker is a device for:
options: a. controlling rotor movement only
b. isolating the service on overload
c. isolating the battery when using the ground batteries
d. earthing the magnetos when switching off

questions.question: A non-trip free circuit breaker is:
options: a. one which can make a circuit in flight by pushing a button
b. a wire placed in a conductor which melts under overload
c. an on-off type tumbler switch
d. another type of voltage regulator

questions.question: A non-trip free circuit breaker that has tripped due to overload:
options: a. can never be reset
b. can only be reset on the ground by a maintenance engineer
c. can be reset and held in if necessary
d. cannot be reset while the fault is still there

questions.question: A thermal circuit breaker works on the principle of:
options: a. differential expansion of metals
b. differential thickness of metals
c. differential density of metals
d. differential pressure of metals

questions.question: Circuit breakers are fitted in:
options: a. series with the load
b. parallel with the load
c. across the load
d. shunt with the load

questions.question: A fuse is said to have blown when:
options: a. an excess current has burst the outer cover and disconnected the circuit from the supply
b. the circuit is reconnected
c. a current of a higher value than the fuse rating has melted the conductor and disconnected the circuit from the supply
d. the amperage has been sufficiently high to cause the fuse to trip out of its holder and has therefore, disconnected the circuit from the supply

questions.question: In a fused circuit the fuse is:
options: a. in parallel with the load
b. in series with the load
c. in the conductor between generator and regulator
d. only fitted when loads are in series

questions.question: Overloading an electrical circuit causes the fuse to 'Blow'. This:
options: a. increases the weight of the insulation
b. fractures the fuse case
c. disconnects the fuse from its holder
d. melts the fuse wire

questions.question: What must be checked before replacing a fuse?
options: a. The ohms of the circuit
b. The amps being used in the circuit
c. The amps capacity of the consuming device in the circuit
d. The correct fuse volt or watts rating

questions.question: The size of fuse required for an electrical circuit whose power is 72 watts and whose voltage is 24 volts is:
options: a. 24 amps
b. 10 amps
c. 5 amps
d. 15 amps

questions.question: When selecting a fuse for an aircraft circuit the governing factor is:
options: a. the voltage of the circuit
b. cable cross-sectional area
c. resistance of the circuit
d. power requirements of the circuit

questions.question: A fuse in an electrical circuit is 'blown' by:
options: a. cooler air
b. the breaking of the glass tube
c. excess voltage breaking the fuse wire
d. excess current rupturing the fuse wire

questions.question: A fuse is used to protect an electrical circuit, it is:
options: a. of low melting point
b. of high capacity
c. of high melting point
d. of low resistance

questions.question: Fuses:
options: a. protect the load
b. protect the cable
c. protect the generator
d. protect both the circuit cable and load

questions.question: A current limiter:
options: a. is a fuse with a low melting point
b. is a circuit breaker
c. is a fuse with a high melting point
d. is a fuse enclosed in a quartz or sand
